document.docAuthor: Smith-Pardo, Allan H., Carpenter, James M. & Kimsey, Lynn
document.masterDocTitle: The Diversity of Hornets in the Genus Vespa (Hymenoptera: Vespidae; Vespinae), Their Importance and Interceptions in the United States

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Diversity of Hornets in the Genus Vespa (Hymenoptera: Vespidae; Vespinae), Their Importance and Interceptions in the United States

heading.emphasis: Keys to the Queens and Workers of the

Species of
Vespa
of the World

paragraph.keyLead:
1 Posterior ocelli about as close to compound eye as to each other ( Fig. 2c ) .................................................
binghami du Buysson

2 Apical margin of clypeus with medial tooth between laterally produced margins ( Fig. 2e ) ..............................
analis Fabricius

4 Metasomal terga 3–6 black, or at most with narrow apical band on tergum 3 ( Fig. 3c ) ............................
soror du Buysson

- Metasomal segments 3–6 with orange apical band, tergum 6 mostly orange (as in Fig. 3d ) .......................
mandarinia Smith

6 Clypeus mostly black ( Fig. 4e ); metasomal terga mostly black or at most with yellow apical band on tergum 1 ( Fig. 5a ) ............................................................................
fervida Smith

- Clypeus yellow ( Fig. 4f ); metasomal terga 1–5 often with apical yellow band ( Fig. 5b ) ...............................
luctuosa de Saussure

9 Vertex black ( Fig. 8c ) and first three metasomal terga primarily orange-yellow ( Fig. 7a ) ....................
philippinensis de Saussure

10 Metasomal terga never entirely black; metasomal tergum 2 with broad orange-yellow band extending one-third or more across tergum ( Fig. 7c and d )...............................
ducalis Smith

11 Metasomal terga 2, 5 and 6 reddish brown or dark brown; tergum 3 and usually tergum 4 mostly yellow, with basal reddish brown band extending medially and two small, lateral reddish brown spots ( Fig. 9a and b ).................
orientalis Linnaeus
- Metasomal terga coloration not as above .............................12

13 Scutellar punctures small and separated two puncture diameters ( Fig. 10a ); metasomal tergum 2 mostly black ( Fig. 10c ) ...........................................................
mocsaryana du Buysson

- Scutellar punctures large and contiguous or separated by 1 puncture diameter or less ( Fig. 10b ); metasomal tergum 2 usually reddish brown ( Fig. 10d ), or if metasomal tergum is mostly black then the vertex is also black.....
affinis (Linnaeus)

14 Clypeus strongly bulging medially, strongly convex in side view ( Fig. 11a ) ...............................................
fumida van der Vecht

15 Metasomal segments 3–5 mostly yellow ( Fig. 11c ); vertex orange-yellow to red .......................................
crabro Linnaeus

- Metasomal segments 3–5 mostly dark brown or black, some segments with narrow distal yellow band ( Fig. 11d ); vertex reddish to dark brown ........................................
dybowskii André

16 Clypeus ( Fig. 12a ) and metanotum with dark markings ................................................................
multimaculata Pérez

17 Clypeus yellow with black markings ( Fig. 12a ), or if without markings then metanotum entirely yellow (as in Fig. 12c and d ) ................................................................
bellicosa de Saussure

18 Scutellum and metanotum entirely or primarily yellow ( Fig. 12d ) and vertex black.............................
bicolor Fabricius

19 Scutal punctures small, separated by 2–3 puncture diameters ( Fig. 13a ); metasomal terga 2–5 entirely black.....
basalis Smith

20 Clypeal punctation uniformly distributed ........
simillima Smith

21 Side of prothorax close to spiracle smooth ( Fig. 13c ); vertex not black; mesothorax and propodeum with same coloration; terga 2 and 5 black or mostly black................................
vivax Smith

- Side of prothorax close to spiracle rugose ( Fig. 13d ); without above color combination ………..………...…
velutina Lepeletier
